docs.lead_paragraph: Heeding President Bush, the House today approved a Republican bill to place the federal government in charge of airport security without turning 28,000 baggage and passenger screeners into federal workers. The critical vote on the measure occurred when the House narrowly rejected a Senate bill to create an additional federal work force, by a vote of 218 to 214, handing Mr. Bush a hard-fought victory.

headline.main: BUSH'S APPROACH ON PLANE SECURITY CHOSEN BY HOUSE

docs.abstract: House, heeding Pres Bush's appeals, approves Republican bill to place federal government in charge of airport security but without turning 28,000 baggage and passenger screeners into federal workers; narrow vote of 218-214 rejects Senate approach that would create additional federal work force; Bush, who personally asked moderate lawmakers to allow him flexibility on airline security, urges both houses to work out final bill; vote on Republican plan is 286-139; Sen John McCain expects Senate to stand firm on its 100-0 vote for federalized force; says public deserves same safety as members of Congress insist on for themselves; photo with bipartisan ally Richard Gephardt; competing bills compared; Republican leaders lobbied members with offers of perks; House version would set up agency to oversee security, set standards and test and train personnel, who would get higher pay and have to be US citizens (M)
docs.snippet: Heeding President Bush, the House today approved a Republican bill to place the federal government in charge of airport security without turning 28,000 baggage and passenger screeners into federal workers.    The critical vote on the measure occurred...

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday President Bush bluntly encouraged Congress to ''get to work'' on an economic stimulus package and bring a bill to his desk by the end of this month. The matter is indeed urgent, and the combination of quick action by Congress and steady rates from the Federal Reserve offer the best hope for turning the economy around. Gross domestic product shrank by 0.4 percent in the third quarter of this year. That performance was better than most analysts expected, but still the worst in a decade. The economy is probably contracting even faster now, and the recovery many had hoped to see by year's end is not likely to arrive until well into 2002.
docs.abstract: Editorial on third-quarter economic contraction calls for Federal Reserve to signal long period of loose credit at stable rates and for Congress to approve fiscal stimulus package that targets those most in need
docs.snippet: Yesterday President Bush bluntly encouraged Congress to ''get to work'' on an economic stimulus package and bring a bill to his desk by the end of this month. The matter is indeed urgent, and the combination of quick action by Congress and steady...

docs.lead_paragraph: Planning and Diplomacy MORE MILITARY ADVISERS -- The Pentagon is planning to expand the number of advisers working with anti-Taliban groups in Afghanistan, who will move with the resistance forces as they advance against Taliban troops. The deployment reflects a new determination by the United States to help the rebels, the Northern Alliance, seize territory. A1 UNEASE IN EUROPE -- Prime Minister Tony Blair began another diplomatic mission -- this time to the Middle East -- but in Britain and elsewhere in Europe, public unease with the course of the war in Afghanistan and its rationale was on the rise. B2

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's looming financial crisis, while serious, was not unmanageable and that private businesses, not aid from the federal government, would ultimately determine how well the city comes through it. Mr. Bloomberg, the Republican nominee for mayor, referred repeatedly to his experience running Bloomberg L.P., the big communications company that he founded in 1981, as his main preparation for the top job at City Hall.

headline.main: Bloomberg Stresses Private Business As Key to Revival

docs.abstract: Michael R Bloomberg, in interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, says his business experience makes him better prepared than his mayoral opponent, Mark Green, to handle New York City's economic problems; frames his view of city and its problems through constructs of successful entrepreneur who would approach mayor's work with pragmatism and salesmanship gleaned from private enterprise; expresses surprise with those who accuse him of trying to buy election with his private fortune; he has spent record $41 million on campaign; says city's looming financial crisis is serious but not unmanageable and that private businesses, not aid from federal government, would ultimately determine how well city comes through it; says he doubts that city and state would get much more than $20 billion in emergency relief already approved in Washington following Sept 11 terrorist attacks; predicts that beyond money for cleanup and transit repairs, city would have to depend on private financing for most projects (M)
docs.snippet: Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's looming financial crisis, while serious, was not unmanageable and that private businesses, not aid from the federal government, would ultimately determine how well the city comes through it.    Mr....

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Our members,'' said John Turchiano, ''have never been in this position before.'' Mr. Turchiano is a spokesman for the Hotel and Restaurant Workers union in New York City. On Monday four tractor-trailer trucks from the group Feed the Children pulled up outside the union's health center in Elmhurst, Queens. Nearly 500 union members and their families lined up for canned goods, baby food, toothpaste and other items that might be helpful for families suddenly thrown into an economic crisis. Worried expressions were the norm. Some of the union members wept.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column holds many people underestimate emotional and economic impact of terrorist disaster in New York; notes enormous number of low-wage workers, many without health or unemployment benefits, have lost jobs; cites need for federal aid (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Confronted with the firmest evidence yet that the country has slipped into recession, President Bush demanded today that Congress break a partisan deadlock and send him an economic recovery package within the next month. Speaking to business executives at the White House after the government reported that the economy shrank in the third quarter -- the first quarterly downturn since 1993 -- Mr. Bush said he was ''deeply concerned'' about rising unemployment, declining consumer confidence and deteriorating business conditions.

headline.main: Bush Sets Nov. 30 Deadline For Economic Stimulus Plan

docs.abstract: Pres Bush, with news of economy shrinking in third quarter, demands that Congress break bipartisan deadlock and send him economic stimulus package by end of November; Sen Tom Daschle says he will not compromise on focus of recovery package, which, he contends, needs to be on working people and unemployed (M)
docs.snippet: Confronted with the firmest evidence yet that the country has slipped into recession, President Bush demanded today that Congress break a partisan deadlock and send him an economic recovery package within the next month.    Speaking to business...

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States shifted gears in its military campaign against Osama bin Laden and his Taliban protectors. Officials said that more teams of American advisers will be slipped into Afghanistan to work with rebel militias like the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance. MORE HELP ON THE GROUND -- With some United States allies beginning to squirm at the relatively slow pace of events, the Pentagon seemed newly determined to help the rebels seize territory rather than leaving them to their own devices. Some American teams were already on the ground, and military officers credited them with allowing warplanes, especially warhorse B-52 bombers, to hit their targets with much greater precision.

headline.main: Plan for More G.I.'s on the Ground, Economic Slump, Anthrax Unease
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: OCT. 31, 2001

docs.abstract: Overview of situation in war against terrorism; more ground soldiers will be deployed in Afghanistan and using B-52 bombers allows airstrikes to hit targets with more precision; government figures confirm end of longest economic expansion in country's history, and Sept 11 attacks play part in decline; death of Kathy T Nguyen from inhalation anthrax compounds fears of public, as it is not known how she contracted it (M)
